Subjective: Back pain radiating down right leg via back and side to foot; 1.5 weeks duration; worsened over time; interferes with sleep and work; tried paracetamol and ibuprofen with no relief; no fever, no headache; no smoking/alcohol; Request: Wants pain relief and resolution of symptoms.
Objective: BP: not recorded; HR: not recorded; RR: not recorded; Temp: not recorded; Physical exam: tenderness in right lower back; decreased sensation in right lower leg; strength in right leg preserved but painful; reflexes intact; no abnormalities in left leg.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, suspected herniated nucleus pulposus (HNP); no signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: • Start pregabalin for pain relief, with gradual dose escalation; • Physiotherapy to improve back flexibility and reduce nerve compression; • Follow-up telephone appointment in 1 week to assess pain relief; • Safety net: contact GP or out-of-hours service if symptoms worsen, including loss of sensation in 'riding breeches area', inability to urinate or defecate, or significant weakness in right leg.
